awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Surface functionalization to promote beneficial biofilm formation and stability
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Harmful biofilms cause many major problems in human health and the environment. Instead of developing strategies to prevent biofilm formation on materials, an alternative approach is to design materials that promote the formation of beneficial biofilms that expel harmful bacteria. In addition to live microbes, the major component of biofilms is the extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) secreted by the microbes. In this collaborative project, researchers will modify materials surface with specific biologically active molecules and investigate their role on the formation and stability of the biofilms and EPS. Increasing body of evidence has indicated that different material surfaces may strongly influence the properties of a biofilm. However, the underlying mechanism and the role of the immobilized biologically active molecules on EPS secretion and biofilm formation are largely unknown.  The proposed research project aims to bridge this important gap of knowledge which will facilitate development of surface biofunctionalization to promote formation of stable beneficial biofilms. Furthermore, this collaborative project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate students including underrepresented students in biomaterials technology and data science, especially in analyzing large datasets consisting of thousands of biomacromolecules and elucidating their functions. 

PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This collaborative project aims to gain understanding on how surface presentation of multiple ligands affects the formation and stability of beneficial bacterial biofilms as well as their extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). The investigators will employ their surface functionalization methods to present a variety of strong and specific ligands targeting various bacterial surface components on silicone surfaces. They will determine the effect of such surfaces on biofilm formation by two non-pathogenic E. coli strains. They will also evaluate the long-term stability of such biofilms against the challenge by other bacteria using their unique high-throughput flow biofilm reactor system.  The EPS components secreted by the bacteria throughout the biofilm life cycle will be identified and quantified by state-of-the-art mass spectrometry. The data is expected to provide new insights into how EPS are developed during biofilm formation and shed light on their biological functions. Guided by the knowledge generated from the study, the investigators will explore the potential of tailoring the surface presentation of specific ligands to “program” the formation of biofilms with desired properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biofilms are communities of bacteria that stick to surfaces. They are commonly associated with infections and environmental issues. However, not all biofilms are harmful. Some beneficial bacteria form biofilms that help prevent pathogenic colonization. Instead of trying to eliminate all biofilms, our long-term objective is to explore ways to promote beneficial bacterial biofilms to naturally outcompete harmful bacteria, particularly in medical settings such as urinary catheters.

Intellectual Merits. In this project, we focused on modifying the surfaces of silicone (one of the most common materials used in medical devices, such as urinary catheters), to encourage the growth of beneficial bacteria. Specifically, we coated silicone urinary catheters with specific biologically active molecules called ligands, including mannosides (a carbohydrate found on cell surfaces), which bind to protein receptors on bacterial surfaces and help stabilize biofilms. The study found that the strength of these ligand-bacteria interactions directly affected how well biofilms formed and how stable they remained over time.

A key breakthrough was discovering that despite human urine contains only tiny amounts of proteins (urinary proteins), these proteins rapidly deposited on urinary catheters upon contact. The deposited urinary proteins promoted the biofilm formations by beneficial bacteria although they do not have the mannoside receptors. Using mass spectrometry, we identified over a thousand of deposited urinary proteins, and identified a few of them that promoted biofilm formation by beneficial bacteria, such as a specific strain of E. coli, which could potentially prevent harmful bacterial infections. We also identified over a thousand bacterial proteins in the bacterial extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). These molecules played a crucial role in biofilm stability and resistance to invading harmful bacteria.

One of the primary applications of this research is in preventing catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs). We pre-coated the urinary catheters with beneficial bacteria, and challenged them by multidrug-resistant pathogens. While the beneficial E. coli biofilms initially provided some protection, highly aggressive pathogens, like the ST131 strain of E. coli, were able to overtake them. This led us to explore combining beneficial bacteria with bacteriophages (viruses that specifically target harmful bacteria) to create a more effective infection-prevention strategy.

Broader Impact:  Beyond medical applications, this research has implications for environmental sustainability, agriculture, and materials science. Understanding how biofilms develop on different surfaces can help design materials that resist contamination in industrial and natural settings. Additionally, this project trained graduate and undergraduate students in cutting-edge biomaterials research and data science techniques.

The project also resulted in high-throughput systems for studying biofilms under realistic conditions, including a catheter model that simulates fluid flow inside the human body. We also created powerful mass spectrometry techniques to analyze proteins in biofilms at an unprecedented level of detail. The availability of these tools will help advancing the research on biofilms and biomaterials for controlling biofilms. 

Overall, this study contributed to harnessing beneficial bacteria to prevent infections and improve biomedical devices. By precisely engineering surface coatings and understanding biofilm biology, innovative solutions can be developed to combat harmful bacteria in healthcare and beyond.
